answers.answer: I hear you! We "make too much money" on paper but we have debt so it's not like we're making off with buckets of cash every pay period. I'm a teacher and my husband works in finance. A lot of good trying to live the right way (I.e. not ripping the govt off) does us.

My husband and I too are both workin class and I've had I quit working because I now have preeclampsia with this pregnancy. That is why my husband after leaving the active duty army made sure he stayed on in the national guard. We only pay $204 a month for insurance and it covers all family members. It also covers my pregnancy 100% and when I go to have the baby we only pay $25 the first day and $17 a day after that, that I have I been the hospital. Obviously this isn't a choice for everyone but maybe your hubby can join the weekend warrior squad and reap the benefits. We also get amazing dental and full base privileges as well and with me not working right now, we actually qualify for WIC, for the time being.

I am so thankful for my husbands job because our insurance premium is like $50 a month and it covers all our medical, dental, vision, and prescription plan. They also give him paid time off after baby is born.

We are constantly told "we make too much money" i dont qualify for any type of assistance. It's tough but I knew this was going to happen so I planned ahead. I saved my income tax return money.  Im thankful that my job allows me to pay weekly or it can be deducted once I return on a weekly basis.

My hubby would join the guard if he could but he has had gastric bypass surgery and they won't take you after that.Oh another note. We work together for the same company. We work 85 miles from our home so when I go on leave if he doesn't he will actually be spending more money to work with the fuel cost then he will be bring home. Bless us folks that try to do better then government help but after adding it up I just want to give up and be lazy instead of working in this heat this summer. 17 weeks left until the best thing about this whole situation comes to say hello. Then the stress and worry and expense will all be worth it.
Oh and we have plenty of money in savings but I wasn't expecting to spend it all and be flat broke when I go back to work after baby.
The us is pretty bad for anything maternity

Sadly this country we live in does not support family life or childbearing.  Its my understanding that in other countries, like the UK and Canada moms are treated much better.  Its sad really.My job doesnt provide any health benefits at all and when I go on maternity leave its unpaid. I do qualify for medicaid and wic but not food or cash help. Then the cost of daycare is ridiculously high here and I cant get assistance on that either.  I dont think ill be able to take more than 6wks off of work since its unpaid.

In the US its true that our maternity leave is pretty terrible and our healthcare can be expensive, however when it comes to actual care the US is far better than other countries. We have friends that live in the UK and hear their stories about healthcare.
At 36 weeks u can go on disability

That's Obama care at work for us. My deductible for a surgery last year was 1800 after I've been paying all this time and numerous doctor appointments. I switched to kaiser health care and am much happier

My husband and I are in the same boat. Even if one of us stopped working, we would still exceed the income level for assistance. I am lucky to receive short term disability for 6 weeks at 100% pay or 8 with a c-section. I will also keep my health benefits. Granted when tax time rolls around the extra deduction from the baby will be eaten up by the taxes not paid on the disability payments. We were not planning on starting a family so soon and went through our savings quick paying medical bills and moving from our 1 bedroom apartment. I don't know how any family making between $30,000-$100,000 affords having a child.
EriuBC I don't know how people do it either, especially on the lower end of that spectrum. Between my husband and I we make just over $200,000 a year and we still have to budget too.
The healthcare system in the US sounds really bad. I honestly dont know how you lot do it. You all derserve a bloody medal mummas!
politicians here care far more about fetuses than families or children - they only talk about family values, then refuse to pass paid maternity leave and cut school funding

I have always been in the poverty level since i was a child. Getting any sort of medical attention is so hard even with state assistance. There is not a dentist for hundreds of miles that will take my coverage because they don't want to wait to get paid. Maternity leave is only six weeks unpaid and if you try to apply for disability, you lose your insurance. I know our prez is trying to do good things but he's ****** us over more than he thinks.

We made right at 50k last year. We live in a paid for 32k house that is really nice in our small town. Both our cars are paid off but it we are going from paying 200 a month for insurance to paying over 500 in Sept. However if we add another baby later my premiums will not go up. So I think I will just have about 40 kids and then maybe we will get some help. Lol

All i can say is, if you pay taxes you should be eligible for any type of assistance. I don't bust my *** so people like my brother and his gf can **** the system over while me and millions of others can pay their way. He's on ssi because he is too damn lazy to get off his *** and lose a few pounds and get a job. That's fraud plain and clear. By the time we hit retirement, there won't be anything for us to live on but a paycheck that we have to earn at 70 years old. What kind of **** is that?

I feel so lucky to live in the uk,we get 36weeks maternity leave paid..no medical expenses. Then things like child tax credits,working taxcredits, income support. There's literally so much help. Ins way I think it's a bad thing as people take advantage of benifits and the government covers most cost of everything. But for those who need it, it's a great help. I work full time but after the baby is born its likely I wont be able to work as my partne is in the army so always has to go away with short notice, we have no family locally so I would have to be home to look after the baby. It's not what I want to do at all,I want to provide for my baby. But I'm glad help is there if worse comes to worse x

I understand where all you ladies are coming from. I just keep thinking and feeling that god gives life and if he brought us to it he will bring us through it. Good luck ladies I know it's frustrating and hard but we will make it

question: I completely understand why the lower middle class working people have pretty much quit having children. My hubby and myself work. We do ok. It could be worse. We don't have any debt. No house payment or anything. Found out today that if I want to keep my insurance at work whenI go on fmla which where I work is completely unpaid I will have to pay in advance for the insurance. Well that isn't to bad however my premiums a month once the baby is born will exceed 500 bucks. So I basically have to pay them 2k before I get my leave because I can take 16 weeks off. And when I go to the hospital to have the baby I have to pay my deductible which is almost 2500 bucks. So before I pay my bills for the time off work I have to come up with almost 5k. We make to much money for wic, food stamps or Medicaid with is both working. Oh and I also found out that when my doctor puts me on light duty my employer just sends you home instead of putting me in the office and letting you keep working.  So sorry for the rambling but that is my vent for today. Hope you all can see why I am feeling defeated today.
title: I completely understand....
